shortLinksItems.hed: Top 30 Resorts in Florida: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
shortLinksItems.dek: Golf, beaches, getaway islands—Florida has it all. From the Gulf and Central Florida to the Atlantic and the Keys, here are the 30 resorts named the best by *Condé Nast Traveler* readers.

items.title: __TOP 15 RESORTS (ATLANTIC and THE KEYS)__
items.caption: These beautiful resorts offer plenty of oceanfront real estate, along with family-friendly amenities, island getaways, and—in some cases—attractions for adults only.

items.title: [#15. Ritz-Carlton, Fort Lauderdale](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/fort-lauderdale/ritz-carlton--fort-lauderdale)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.232*

__Good for:__ The [Ritz-Carlton, Fort Lauderdale](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/fort-lauderdale/ritz-carlton--fort-lauderdale) has been said to epitomize the glamour of a long-gone era. Water views, oceanfront cabanas, an infinity pool, a spa, poolside cocktails, it's not exactly an environment for children but is perfect for couples on a romantic retreat.

items.title: [#14. The Seagate Hotel & Spa, Delray Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/delray-beach/seagate-hotel---spa--delray-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.874*

__Good for:__ Couples and families. Be aware that "by the ocean" does not mean "on the ocean"—you'll need to walk or take a trolley to the water. Inside the hotel you can surround yourself with 7,000 gallon aquariums and a 2,500 gallon shark tank.

items.title: [#13. The Breakers, Palm Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-beach/the-breakers--palm-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.103*

__Good for:__ Couples looking for a romantic escape on this barrier island, and families who need to spend more time together—a la carte activity scheduling is available for parents and children. Guests needing more space can always book the 1,700-square-foot Imperial Designer Suite. Fun fact: When the Breakers first opened in 1904, rooms went for $4 a night and came with three meals.

items.title: [#12. Ritz-Carlton, Amelia Island](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/fernandina-beach/ritz-carlton--amelia-island)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.443*

__Good for:__ On a barrier island 35 miles from Jacksonville, this casually elegant resort should appeal to both couples looking to get away, and to families, as there's plenty of activities to keep the kids occupied. Fun fact: Amelia Island is the only place in the United States to have been under the authority of eight different flags, and commemorates this fact with a shrimp festival in Fernandina the first weekend in May.

items.title: [#11. Parrot Key Hotel & Resort, Key West](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/key-west/parrot-key-hotel-and-resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.655*

__Good for:__ Couples. Located on Florida Bay about two-and-a-half miles from busy Duval Street, the Parrot Key was built in the Key West Conch style, with shady porches and gingerbread details. It’s home to an art gallery and sculpture garden showcasing regional and international artwork.

items.title: [#10. Little Palm Island Resort & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/summerland-key/little-palm-island-resort---spa--little-torch-key)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 85.369*

__Good for:__ Couples serious about getting away from it all (children under 16 are not allowed). Reached only by sea plane or boat, Little Palm's air-conditioned thatched-roof bungalows have no TVs, telephones, or Wi-Fi.

items.title: [#9. Ponte Vedra Inn & Club, Ponte Vedra Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/jacksonville-beach/ponte-vedra-inn---club--ponte-vedra-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 85.897*

__Good for:__ Couples and families. The 300-acre beachfront inn first opened in 1928, and country club-style personal service is still the norm. Fun fact: The Ponte Vedra site was once a mining town, excavated for ore during World War 1.

items.title: [#8. Pelican Grand Beach Resort, Fort Lauderdale](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/fort-lauderdale/pelican-grand-beach-resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.740*

__Good for:__ Couples, who will appreciate the Pelican's retro-romantic Old Florida ambiance, which it has managed to preserve despite remodeling and such new-fangled items as the "zero entry" pool.

items.title: [#7. Hammock Beach Resort, Palm Coast](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-coast/hammock-beach-resort--palm-coast)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 87.534*

__Good for:__ Diehard golfers, with signature design greens by Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson—you can see the Atlantic from six holes, and families. Kids can zip down the water chute or float along the Lazy River, while you relax from your golf game with a cocktail and a round of billiards at the Loggerheads Lounge.

items.title: [#6. Eau Palm Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/palm-beach/eau-palm-beach-resort-formerly-ritz-carlton)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 87.825*

__Good for:__ Couples and families who want to recapture the nonchalant opulence of a traditional Palm Beach estate—here, your stay begins with a welcome drink of Champagne. The on-site spa is particularly luxurious, with different treatments, private garden rooms, and even a “self-centered garden” where you can reflect.

items.title: [#5. St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/miami/st--regis-bal-harbour-resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.309*

__Good for:__ Couples and families looking to escape the South Beach frenzy, hate "Florida casual," and appreciate having a Jean-Georges restaurant on the premises. Despite the glitz, the resort also offers kid-friendly perks through the St. Regis Children's Club.

items.title: [#4. Sunset Key Guest Cottages (Westin), Key West](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/key-w/sunset-key-guest-cottage--key-west)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.403*

__Good for:__ Couples and families who want to keep bustling Key West at a distance, as this community of pastel-colored cottages that can only be reached by boat.

items.title: [#3. Acqualina Resort & Spa on the Beach, Sunny Isles Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/n-miami-beach/acqualina-resort---spa--miami-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.646*

__Good for:__ Couples and families. This Mediterranean-inspired 52-story tower may have adults-only amenities—including one pool where kids aren’t allowed—but it remains family-friendly, with an AcquaMarine children's program.
items.credit: Courtesy Acqualina Resort & Spa on the Beach

items.title: [#2. One Ocean Resort & Spa, Atlantic Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/atlantic-beach/one-ocean-resort---spa--atlantic-beach--jacksonville)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 89.786*

__Good for:__ Eco-conscious families and couples who thrive on personal attention. It has a kids club whose focus is sea turtles, and personal Docents, who curate stays right down to having your favorite snacks in your room when you arrive. The hotel also has an art gallery, with a new featured artist whose work is on view every six months or so.

items.title: [#1. Pier House Resort & Spa, Key West](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/key-west/pier-house-resort-and-caribbean-spa)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 91.163*

__Good for:__ Couples, who like the seclusion of a private beach but still want to be close to the Duval Street nightlife. Legendary treasure hunter Mel Fisher often finished his day with a drink at the The Chart Room.

items.title: __TOP 15 RESORTS (GULF and CENTRAL)__
items.caption: Central Florida is the ultimate family-friendly destination, thanks to the proliferation of theme parks (Disney, Universal, etc.). But don't overlook its other attractions, including beautiful resorts, golf courses, and more.

items.title: [#15. Ritz-Carlton, Naples](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/ritz-carlton--naples)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 82.880*

__Good for:__ Couples. With a huge 30-treatment room spa, a fitness center, seven restaurants, antiques, artwork, Waterford chandeliers, Asian carpets, and marble baths, this doesn't seem like the ideal place for children. But it's not without some kid-friendly amenities, such as an environmental program and water slides.

items.title: [#14. Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa, Lake Buena Vista](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/orlando/disney-s-saratoga-springs-resort-and-spa)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.141*

__Good for:__ Families. Inspired by New York's historic Saratoga Springs—but with better weather—this large, Victorian-style family-focused resort of studios, villas, pools, and spa is within walking distance of Downtown Disney. Your kids might get a kick out of the Treehouse Villas, which sit ten feet off the ground.

items.title: [#13. Ritz-Carlton Orlando, Grande Lakes](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/ritz-carlton-orlando--grande-lakes)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.341*

__Good for:__ Couples who want to avoid the Orlando-area hubbub and prefer to revel in a 40,000-square-foot spa that offers zero-gravity massages and home-grown organic herb treatments. Still, the resort does draw a large share of families and operates a transfer service to the theme parks, along with a Ritz Kids Club.

items.title: [#12. Marco Island Marriott Beach Resort, Golf Club & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/marco-island/marco-island-marriott-beach-resort--golf-club---spa)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.393*

__Good for:__ Families who like a tropical vibe. Renovated at a cost of $225 million, it includes a free-form fantasy pool with views of the Gulf, eight restaurants, and two upgraded 18-hole golf courses.

items.title: [#11. Sandpearl Resort, Clearwater Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/clearwater-beach/sandpearl-resort--clearwater-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.757*

__Good for:__ Eco-conscious families and couples. The Sandpearl was the first resort in Florida to receive LEED silver certification. Daily programs allow for encounters with dolphins.

items.title: [#10. Disney's Wilderness Lodge, Lake Buena Vista](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/disney-s-wilderness-lodge--lake-buena-vista)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.780*

__Good for:__ Families who want to experience the untamed wilderness of the American Northwest without actually having to go there. The resort features a swimming pool and a Supervised Children's Activity Center, too.

items.title: [#9. Ritz-Carlton Golf Resort, Naples](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/ritz-carlton-golf-resort--naples)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.850*

__Good for:__ Golf aficionados and their partners. It's an Italianate-style golfers' paradise with a country club vibe. All rooms have views of the Greg Norman–designed links, of which there are two.

items.title: [#8. Disney's Animal Kingdom Lodge, Kissimmee](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/kissimmee/disney-s-animal-kingdom-lodge--buena-vista)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.116*

__Good for:__ Families with young children. With more than 30 species of African wildlife here, it's like being on safari in central Florida. If animals aren't enough, there's a Supervised Children's Activity Center, where kids can play games, eat, and—of course—watch Disney movies.

items.title: [#7. Vinoy Renaissance St. Petersburg Resort & Golf Club](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/st-petersburg/vinoy-renaissance-st--petersburg-resort---golf-club)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.177*

__Good for:__ Couples. This Mediterranean Revival behemoth, which opened in 1925, overlooks Tampa Bay. The hotel once served as a training center for Army Air Corps and for military cooks and bakers in the 1940s. It added a Ron Garl golf course in 1992. It's an easy stroll to St. Petersburgh's attractions, such as the Dali Museum.
items.credit: Vinoy Renaissance St. Petersburg Resort & Golf Club

items.title: [#6. The Resort at Longboat Key Club](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/longboat-key/longboat-key-club---resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.672*

Good for: Couples and families, and serious golfers—there's a 45-hole green. It's about a 20-minute drive from downtown Sarasota, and boardwalks reminiscent of Old Florida wind through the 410 acres of tropical grounds. Camp Loggerhead is there for the kids.
items.credit: Courtesy The Resort at Longboat Key Club

items.title: [#5. Disney's Grand Floridian Resort & Spa, Lake Buena Vista](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/disney-s-grand-floridian-resort---spa--lake-buena-vista)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.059*

__Good for:__ Couples both young and old will appreciate recent renovations, which brought Italian marble, stained glass, and shimmering chandeliers to this sumptuous structure. But kids can relax—it's still just one monorail stop from the Magic Kingdom.

items.title: [#4. Gasparilla Inn & Club, Boca Grande](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/boca-grande/gasparilla-inn---club--boca-grande)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.802*

__Good for:__ Couples. Built in 1913, the family-owned Gasparilla has been renovated (it now has a championship Peter Dye golf course) but still evokes the romance of Old Florida. Fun Fact: Henry Ford, Harvey Firestone, Thomas Edison, and Katharine Hepburn all slept here.

items.title: [#3. Arnold Palmer's Bay Hill Club & Lodge, Orlando](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/arnold-palmer-s-bay-hill-club---lodge--orlando)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.830*

__Good for:__ Golf is of course the point here, but there's also a spa, fitness center, and a recognition of other sports, such as tennis and fishing. Quaint and quiet, the ambience is that of a private club, with a dress code enforced at dinner. Palmer, who lives here during the winter, can be frequently seen around the grounds, and the resort has hosted the Arnold Palmer Invitational, part of the PGA tour, since 1979.
items.credit: Courtesy Arnold Palmer's Bay Hill Club & Lodge

items.title: [#2. LaPlaya Beach & Golf Resort, Naples](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/laplaya-beach---golf-resort--naples)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.511*

__Good for:__ Diehard golfers eager to test their skills on the Robert Cupp–designed championship course, and those serious about protecting endangered sea turtles, which share the beach with you.

items.title: [#1. WaterColor Inn & Resort, Santa Rosa Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/santa-rosa-beach/watercolor-inn---resort--santa-rosa-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 91.960*

__Good for:__ This David Rockwell–designed boutique inn should appeal to active families who like their luxuries, and appreciate such small touches as freshly baked cookies served every night at turndown. The resort is a two-minute drive to Seaside, where *The Truman Show* was filmed.

shortLinksItems.hed: Top 10 Free Things to Do in Milan
shortLinksItems.dek: Shopping, eating, and drinking are popular pastimes in Italy’s lively fashion capital; however, this lavish lifestyle doesn’t come cheap. If you’ve exceeded your budget trying to keep up with the local way of life, give your wallet a rest and check out some of our editor [Brando](http://www.likealocalguide.com/editor/milan/670)‘s favorite free things to do in Milan!

items.title: Step back in time at the Basilica di Sant’Ambrogio
items.caption: Dedicated to the patron saint of Milan, [Sant’Ambrogio](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/basilica-di-santambrogio/) is one of the oldest churches in the city and one of the finest examples of Romanesque architecture in Italy. It’s perfectly preserved thanks to numerous restorations, and its historical significance is second only to the Duomo cathedral. Exhibitions and other events occasionally take place in the atrium. Free guided tours are available every Saturday—for bookings, send an email to pietrevivemilano@gmail.com.

items.title: Check out world-class photo exhibitions at Carla Sozzani Gallery
items.caption: Set in a beautiful courtyard at the heart of [10 Corso Como](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/10-corso-como/), this place is a much-loved local photo gallery with fantastic rotating exhibitions. Spare yourself a bit of time to enjoy the art and soak up the creative atmosphere. Most of the exhibitions are free, but keep in mind that some may require an entrance fee. [The gallery](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/carla-sozzani-gallery/) is open daily from 10:30 am–7:30 pm (later on Wednesdays and Thursdays).

items.title: Get your museum fix at the Castle Museums
items.caption: After the unification of Italy, Sforzesco Castle was returned to the city of Milan. Today it houses [seven museums](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/castle-museums/): the Museum of Ancient Art; the Sforza Castle Pinacoteca art gallery; the Museum of Musical Instruments; the Egyptian Museum; the Archaeological Museum; the Applied Arts Collection of Milan and the Antique Furniture and Wooden Sculpture Museum. Free admission every Tuesday from 2–5:30 pm; Wednesday–Friday from 4:30–5 pm.

items.title: Admire underwater creatures at the Civic Aquarium of Milan
items.caption: [This aquarium](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/civic-aquarium-of-milan/) is housed in a stunning Art Nouveau building at the edge of [Sempione Park](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/parco-sempione/) next to the Civic Arena. After undergoing major renovations, the building reopened in 2006 with a new section dedicated to the marine world and another dedicated to fishing. There is free admission on the first Sunday of every month.

items.title: Hang out with locals at Colonne di San Lorenzo
items.caption: [Colonne di San Lorenzo](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/colonne-di-san-lorenzo/) is a place of great historical and architectural charm. Over the past decade or so, it has become one of the most popular nightlife spots for young people in Milan, who gather here, especially in summer, to drink, play, make noise, and have fun until the crack of dawn. Drop by to admire the magnificence of the Roman ruins and the Basilica di San Lorenzo, which is located on the opposite side of the square.

items.title: See impressive 19th-century art at GAM Milano
items.caption: Villa Reale, also known as Villa Belgioioso, is a beautiful example of neoclassical architecture. Its English garden was the first of its kind in Milan. Located inside Villa Reale, [GAM Milano](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/gam-milano/) houses the largest municipal collection of 19th-century artworks in Italy. There is free admission to the gallery from 4:30 pm daily and from 2 pm on Tuesdays.

items.title: Stroll along the canals at Navigli and Porta Ticinese
items.caption: The districts of [Navigli and Porta Ticinese](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/navigli-porta-ticinese/) have been important places for trade and commerce since the Middle Ages because of the canals and waterways that run through them. Today, this area is the heart of Milan’s nightlife, with streets full of lively bars and restaurants. It’s a great place for a relaxing waterside stroll and people watching.

items.title: Discover underground art and culture at MACAO
items.caption: The [MACAO](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/macao/) art project began in 2012 with the "occupation" of an empty skyscraper in downtown Milan. After various adventures (including being evicted from the skyscraper by police), its founders relocated to an old slaughterhouse in the city’s eastern suburbs to continue promoting underground culture and political participation. Now, MACAO has become a permanent meeting place for art-loving locals and visitors.

items.title: Escape the city rush at Parco Sempione
items.caption: Located between the beautiful Arco della Pace (“Arch of Peace”) and Castello Sforzesco (“Sforza Castle”), [Parco Sempione](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/parco-sempione/) is a charming place to spend a relaxing day. It has a peaceful atmosphere (rare for central Milan), making it one of the most-loved parks in the city. If you’re a fan of basketball, exciting matches take place between local youths at the little court near the amphitheater.

items.title: Unleash your inner geek at Milan Natural History Museum
items.caption:
The [Natural History Museum](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/milan-natural-history-museum/) is one of the oldest public cultural institutions in Milan. It was officially opened in 1844 on the site of an old convent, and the collections were moved to the Museum’s current location in the Porta Venezia public gardens at the beginning of the 19th century. It regularly hosts exhibitions and other events of great international importance, however its appeal is linked to its permanent palaeontology, mineralogy, zoology, botany, and entomology exhibitions. There is free admission on the first Sunday of every month.

fields.name: Like a Local
fields.shortBio: Like A Local Guide is all about finding those cool and hidden spots that locals like to hang out at and missing the tourist traps. We have built a website and mobile app to bring the tips of locals around the world to your fingertips.

shortLinksItems.hed: Fall in Love With These Heart-Shaped Islands Around the World
shortLinksItems.dek: Love isn't just in the air—these heart-shaped islands prove it's in the water too.

items.title: Heart Reef, Australia
items.caption: This coral reef was discovered on the Great Barrier Reef back in 1975 and has been a popular tourist attraction ever since. [Air Whitsunday](http://www.airwhitsunday.com.au/) offers a number of sightseeing tours by land and water, but choose either the Panorama or the Reef & Whitehaven Scenic tour to ensure prime aerial viewing of the reef.

items.title: Galesnjak, Dalmatian Coast
items.caption: Romantics will be hard-pressed to find a more heart-shaped island than Galesnjak, which our  [Maphead expert Ken Jennings](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-09-08/is-this-the-worlds-most-adorable-island) recently called "the world's most adorable island." The fact that it's currently uninhabited doesn't stop couples from visiting, and the island's owners hope to host weddings some day.

items.title: Tavarua Island Resort, Fiji
items.caption: Romantics rejoice: [Tavarua](http://www.tavarua.com/) is one of the few heart-shaped islands where couples can actually stay. The all-inclusive tropical paradise features a private beach, 16 cottages, and plenty of watersports: perfect for a honeymoon.

items.title: Sarakiniko Beach, Greece
items.caption: While Sarakiniko Beach isn't an island, this heart-shaped beach *is* located on Milos Island, which is halfway between Athens and Crete. If Milos sounds familiar, that's where the famous statue of love goddess Aphrodite (aka Venus de Milo) was found. It's no surprise then that Milos also goes by the "Island of Lovers."

items.title: Mecklenburg Lake District, Germany
items.caption: This adorable island can be found in Mecklenburg Lake, part of Central Europe's largest lake region. The island is uninhabited, but don't let that stop you from a romantic outing by renting a houseboat or canoe to find it.

items.title: Anfi del Mar Resort, Spain
items.caption: The heart-shaped island at [Anfi del Mar Resort](https://anfi.com/) in the Canary Islands may be man-made, but it's a heart-shaped island nonetheless. Currently, the only way to access the island is to belong to the resort's timeshare program.

items.title: Flores Island, Indonesia
items.caption: This little patch of land off of Flores Island doesn't draw the same attention as its more high-profile cousins, just as Flores Island is overshadowed by Bali. But while you may not be able to visit the heart-shaped isle, you can enjoy some romantic downtime in a tropical region that hasn't yet been overdeveloped.

items.title: Petra Island, New York
items.caption: This tiny island made headlines in 2013 when rumors flew that Angelina Jolie bought it as a birthday gift for Brad Pitt for nearly $20 million. Alas, the rumor proved false, but luckily the island is still listed for sale on [Private Islands Online](http://www.privateislandsonline.com/islands/petra-island). About an hour north of New York City, it includes not one, but two houses designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, plus a helicopter pad. The price is "available upon request," but what's the price of true love?

fields.name: Meredith Rosenberg
fields.shortBio: Meredith Rosenberg is a contributing web producer at *Architectural Digest.*
fields.bio: [Meredith Rosenberg](meredithlrosenberg.com) is a contributing web producer and writer at *Architectural Digest.* She’s spent the past decade as a writer and editor, and most recently produced videos for *The Village Voice.* Her travels have taken her from Alaska to Morocco, with India next in her sights. In her downtime she practices as much yoga as possible and fantasizes about yoga (and non-yoga) vacations. She graduated from the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism.

featureContentItems.hed: Top 30 Resorts in Florida: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
featureContentItems.dek: Golf, beaches, getaway islands—Florida has it all. From the Gulf and Central Florida to the Atlantic and the Keys, here are the 30 resorts named the best by *Condé Nast Traveler* readers.

items.title: __TOP 15 RESORTS (ATLANTIC and THE KEYS)__
items.caption: These beautiful resorts offer plenty of oceanfront real estate, along with family-friendly amenities, island getaways, and—in some cases—attractions for adults only.

items.title: [#15. Ritz-Carlton, Fort Lauderdale](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/fort-lauderdale/ritz-carlton--fort-lauderdale)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.232*

__Good for:__ The [Ritz-Carlton, Fort Lauderdale](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/fort-lauderdale/ritz-carlton--fort-lauderdale) has been said to epitomize the glamour of a long-gone era. Water views, oceanfront cabanas, an infinity pool, a spa, poolside cocktails, it's not exactly an environment for children but is perfect for couples on a romantic retreat.

items.title: [#14. The Seagate Hotel & Spa, Delray Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/delray-beach/seagate-hotel---spa--delray-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.874*

__Good for:__ Couples and families. Be aware that "by the ocean" does not mean "on the ocean"—you'll need to walk or take a trolley to the water. Inside the hotel you can surround yourself with 7,000 gallon aquariums and a 2,500 gallon shark tank.

items.title: [#13. The Breakers, Palm Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-beach/the-breakers--palm-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.103*

__Good for:__ Couples looking for a romantic escape on this barrier island, and families who need to spend more time together—a la carte activity scheduling is available for parents and children. Guests needing more space can always book the 1,700-square-foot Imperial Designer Suite. Fun fact: When the Breakers first opened in 1904, rooms went for $4 a night and came with three meals.

items.title: [#12. Ritz-Carlton, Amelia Island](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/fernandina-beach/ritz-carlton--amelia-island)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.443*

__Good for:__ On a barrier island 35 miles from Jacksonville, this casually elegant resort should appeal to both couples looking to get away, and to families, as there's plenty of activities to keep the kids occupied. Fun fact: Amelia Island is the only place in the United States to have been under the authority of eight different flags, and commemorates this fact with a shrimp festival in Fernandina the first weekend in May.

items.title: [#11. Parrot Key Hotel & Resort, Key West](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/key-west/parrot-key-hotel-and-resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.655*

__Good for:__ Couples. Located on Florida Bay about two-and-a-half miles from busy Duval Street, the Parrot Key was built in the Key West Conch style, with shady porches and gingerbread details. It’s home to an art gallery and sculpture garden showcasing regional and international artwork.

items.title: [#10. Little Palm Island Resort & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/summerland-key/little-palm-island-resort---spa--little-torch-key)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 85.369*

__Good for:__ Couples serious about getting away from it all (children under 16 are not allowed). Reached only by sea plane or boat, Little Palm's air-conditioned thatched-roof bungalows have no TVs, telephones, or Wi-Fi.

items.title: [#9. Ponte Vedra Inn & Club, Ponte Vedra Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/jacksonville-beach/ponte-vedra-inn---club--ponte-vedra-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 85.897*

__Good for:__ Couples and families. The 300-acre beachfront inn first opened in 1928, and country club-style personal service is still the norm. Fun fact: The Ponte Vedra site was once a mining town, excavated for ore during World War 1.

items.title: [#8. Pelican Grand Beach Resort, Fort Lauderdale](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/fort-lauderdale/pelican-grand-beach-resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.740*

__Good for:__ Couples, who will appreciate the Pelican's retro-romantic Old Florida ambiance, which it has managed to preserve despite remodeling and such new-fangled items as the "zero entry" pool.

items.title: [#7. Hammock Beach Resort, Palm Coast](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-coast/hammock-beach-resort--palm-coast)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 87.534*

__Good for:__ Diehard golfers, with signature design greens by Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson—you can see the Atlantic from six holes, and families. Kids can zip down the water chute or float along the Lazy River, while you relax from your golf game with a cocktail and a round of billiards at the Loggerheads Lounge.

items.title: [#6. Eau Palm Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/palm-beach/eau-palm-beach-resort-formerly-ritz-carlton)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 87.825*

__Good for:__ Couples and families who want to recapture the nonchalant opulence of a traditional Palm Beach estate—here, your stay begins with a welcome drink of Champagne. The on-site spa is particularly luxurious, with different treatments, private garden rooms, and even a “self-centered garden” where you can reflect.

items.title: [#5. St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/miami/st--regis-bal-harbour-resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.309*

__Good for:__ Couples and families looking to escape the South Beach frenzy, hate "Florida casual," and appreciate having a Jean-Georges restaurant on the premises. Despite the glitz, the resort also offers kid-friendly perks through the St. Regis Children's Club.

items.title: [#4. Sunset Key Guest Cottages (Westin), Key West](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/key-w/sunset-key-guest-cottage--key-west)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.403*

__Good for:__ Couples and families who want to keep bustling Key West at a distance, as this community of pastel-colored cottages that can only be reached by boat.

items.title: [#3. Acqualina Resort & Spa on the Beach, Sunny Isles Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/n-miami-beach/acqualina-resort---spa--miami-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.646*

__Good for:__ Couples and families. This Mediterranean-inspired 52-story tower may have adults-only amenities—including one pool where kids aren’t allowed—but it remains family-friendly, with an AcquaMarine children's program.
items.credit: Courtesy Acqualina Resort & Spa on the Beach

items.title: [#2. One Ocean Resort & Spa, Atlantic Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/atlantic-beach/one-ocean-resort---spa--atlantic-beach--jacksonville)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 89.786*

__Good for:__ Eco-conscious families and couples who thrive on personal attention. It has a kids club whose focus is sea turtles, and personal Docents, who curate stays right down to having your favorite snacks in your room when you arrive. The hotel also has an art gallery, with a new featured artist whose work is on view every six months or so.

items.title: [#1. Pier House Resort & Spa, Key West](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/key-west/pier-house-resort-and-caribbean-spa)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 91.163*

__Good for:__ Couples, who like the seclusion of a private beach but still want to be close to the Duval Street nightlife. Legendary treasure hunter Mel Fisher often finished his day with a drink at the The Chart Room.

items.title: __TOP 15 RESORTS (GULF and CENTRAL)__
items.caption: Central Florida is the ultimate family-friendly destination, thanks to the proliferation of theme parks (Disney, Universal, etc.). But don't overlook its other attractions, including beautiful resorts, golf courses, and more.

items.title: [#15. Ritz-Carlton, Naples](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/ritz-carlton--naples)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 82.880*

__Good for:__ Couples. With a huge 30-treatment room spa, a fitness center, seven restaurants, antiques, artwork, Waterford chandeliers, Asian carpets, and marble baths, this doesn't seem like the ideal place for children. But it's not without some kid-friendly amenities, such as an environmental program and water slides.

items.title: [#14. Disney's Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa, Lake Buena Vista](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/orlando/disney-s-saratoga-springs-resort-and-spa)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.141*

__Good for:__ Families. Inspired by New York's historic Saratoga Springs—but with better weather—this large, Victorian-style family-focused resort of studios, villas, pools, and spa is within walking distance of Downtown Disney. Your kids might get a kick out of the Treehouse Villas, which sit ten feet off the ground.

items.title: [#13. Ritz-Carlton Orlando, Grande Lakes](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/ritz-carlton-orlando--grande-lakes)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.341*

__Good for:__ Couples who want to avoid the Orlando-area hubbub and prefer to revel in a 40,000-square-foot spa that offers zero-gravity massages and home-grown organic herb treatments. Still, the resort does draw a large share of families and operates a transfer service to the theme parks, along with a Ritz Kids Club.

items.title: [#12. Marco Island Marriott Beach Resort, Golf Club & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/marco-island/marco-island-marriott-beach-resort--golf-club---spa)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.393*

__Good for:__ Families who like a tropical vibe. Renovated at a cost of $225 million, it includes a free-form fantasy pool with views of the Gulf, eight restaurants, and two upgraded 18-hole golf courses.

items.title: [#11. Sandpearl Resort, Clearwater Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/clearwater-beach/sandpearl-resort--clearwater-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.757*

__Good for:__ Eco-conscious families and couples. The Sandpearl was the first resort in Florida to receive LEED silver certification. Daily programs allow for encounters with dolphins.

items.title: [#10. Disney's Wilderness Lodge, Lake Buena Vista](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/disney-s-wilderness-lodge--lake-buena-vista)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.780*

__Good for:__ Families who want to experience the untamed wilderness of the American Northwest without actually having to go there. The resort features a swimming pool and a Supervised Children's Activity Center, too.

items.title: [#9. Ritz-Carlton Golf Resort, Naples](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/ritz-carlton-golf-resort--naples)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 83.850*

__Good for:__ Golf aficionados and their partners. It's an Italianate-style golfers' paradise with a country club vibe. All rooms have views of the Greg Norman–designed links, of which there are two.

items.title: [#8. Disney's Animal Kingdom Lodge, Kissimmee](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/kissimmee/disney-s-animal-kingdom-lodge--buena-vista)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.116*

__Good for:__ Families with young children. With more than 30 species of African wildlife here, it's like being on safari in central Florida. If animals aren't enough, there's a Supervised Children's Activity Center, where kids can play games, eat, and—of course—watch Disney movies.

items.title: [#7. Vinoy Renaissance St. Petersburg Resort & Golf Club](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/st-petersburg/vinoy-renaissance-st--petersburg-resort---golf-club)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.177*

__Good for:__ Couples. This Mediterranean Revival behemoth, which opened in 1925, overlooks Tampa Bay. The hotel once served as a training center for Army Air Corps and for military cooks and bakers in the 1940s. It added a Ron Garl golf course in 1992. It's an easy stroll to St. Petersburgh's attractions, such as the Dali Museum.
items.credit: Vinoy Renaissance St. Petersburg Resort & Golf Club

items.title: [#6. The Resort at Longboat Key Club](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/longboat-key/longboat-key-club---resort)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 84.672*

Good for: Couples and families, and serious golfers—there's a 45-hole green. It's about a 20-minute drive from downtown Sarasota, and boardwalks reminiscent of Old Florida wind through the 410 acres of tropical grounds. Camp Loggerhead is there for the kids.
items.credit: Courtesy The Resort at Longboat Key Club

items.title: [#5. Disney's Grand Floridian Resort & Spa, Lake Buena Vista](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/disney-s-grand-floridian-resort---spa--lake-buena-vista)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.059*

__Good for:__ Couples both young and old will appreciate recent renovations, which brought Italian marble, stained glass, and shimmering chandeliers to this sumptuous structure. But kids can relax—it's still just one monorail stop from the Magic Kingdom.

items.title: [#4. Gasparilla Inn & Club, Boca Grande](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/boca-grande/gasparilla-inn---club--boca-grande)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.802*

__Good for:__ Couples. Built in 1913, the family-owned Gasparilla has been renovated (it now has a championship Peter Dye golf course) but still evokes the romance of Old Florida. Fun Fact: Henry Ford, Harvey Firestone, Thomas Edison, and Katharine Hepburn all slept here.

items.title: [#3. Arnold Palmer's Bay Hill Club & Lodge, Orlando](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/arnold-palmer-s-bay-hill-club---lodge--orlando)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 86.830*

__Good for:__ Golf is of course the point here, but there's also a spa, fitness center, and a recognition of other sports, such as tennis and fishing. Quaint and quiet, the ambience is that of a private club, with a dress code enforced at dinner. Palmer, who lives here during the winter, can be frequently seen around the grounds, and the resort has hosted the Arnold Palmer Invitational, part of the PGA tour, since 1979.
items.credit: Courtesy Arnold Palmer's Bay Hill Club & Lodge

items.title: [#2. LaPlaya Beach & Golf Resort, Naples](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/naples/laplaya-beach---golf-resort--naples)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 88.511*

__Good for:__ Diehard golfers eager to test their skills on the Robert Cupp–designed championship course, and those serious about protecting endangered sea turtles, which share the beach with you.

items.title: [#1. WaterColor Inn & Resort, Santa Rosa Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/santa-rosa-beach/watercolor-inn---resort--santa-rosa-beach)
items.caption:
*Readers' Rating: 91.960*

__Good for:__ This David Rockwell–designed boutique inn should appeal to active families who like their luxuries, and appreciate such small touches as freshly baked cookies served every night at turndown. The resort is a two-minute drive to Seaside, where *The Truman Show* was filmed.

featureContentItems.hed: Top 10 Free Things to Do in Milan
featureContentItems.dek: Shopping, eating, and drinking are popular pastimes in Italy’s lively fashion capital; however, this lavish lifestyle doesn’t come cheap. If you’ve exceeded your budget trying to keep up with the local way of life, give your wallet a rest and check out some of our editor [Brando](http://www.likealocalguide.com/editor/milan/670)‘s favorite free things to do in Milan!

items.title: Step back in time at the Basilica di Sant’Ambrogio
items.caption: Dedicated to the patron saint of Milan, [Sant’Ambrogio](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/basilica-di-santambrogio/) is one of the oldest churches in the city and one of the finest examples of Romanesque architecture in Italy. It’s perfectly preserved thanks to numerous restorations, and its historical significance is second only to the Duomo cathedral. Exhibitions and other events occasionally take place in the atrium. Free guided tours are available every Saturday—for bookings, send an email to pietrevivemilano@gmail.com.

items.title: Check out world-class photo exhibitions at Carla Sozzani Gallery
items.caption: Set in a beautiful courtyard at the heart of [10 Corso Como](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/10-corso-como/), this place is a much-loved local photo gallery with fantastic rotating exhibitions. Spare yourself a bit of time to enjoy the art and soak up the creative atmosphere. Most of the exhibitions are free, but keep in mind that some may require an entrance fee. [The gallery](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/carla-sozzani-gallery/) is open daily from 10:30 am–7:30 pm (later on Wednesdays and Thursdays).

items.title: Get your museum fix at the Castle Museums
items.caption: After the unification of Italy, Sforzesco Castle was returned to the city of Milan. Today it houses [seven museums](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/castle-museums/): the Museum of Ancient Art; the Sforza Castle Pinacoteca art gallery; the Museum of Musical Instruments; the Egyptian Museum; the Archaeological Museum; the Applied Arts Collection of Milan and the Antique Furniture and Wooden Sculpture Museum. Free admission every Tuesday from 2–5:30 pm; Wednesday–Friday from 4:30–5 pm.

items.title: Admire underwater creatures at the Civic Aquarium of Milan
items.caption: [This aquarium](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/civic-aquarium-of-milan/) is housed in a stunning Art Nouveau building at the edge of [Sempione Park](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/parco-sempione/) next to the Civic Arena. After undergoing major renovations, the building reopened in 2006 with a new section dedicated to the marine world and another dedicated to fishing. There is free admission on the first Sunday of every month.

items.title: Hang out with locals at Colonne di San Lorenzo
items.caption: [Colonne di San Lorenzo](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/colonne-di-san-lorenzo/) is a place of great historical and architectural charm. Over the past decade or so, it has become one of the most popular nightlife spots for young people in Milan, who gather here, especially in summer, to drink, play, make noise, and have fun until the crack of dawn. Drop by to admire the magnificence of the Roman ruins and the Basilica di San Lorenzo, which is located on the opposite side of the square.

items.title: See impressive 19th-century art at GAM Milano
items.caption: Villa Reale, also known as Villa Belgioioso, is a beautiful example of neoclassical architecture. Its English garden was the first of its kind in Milan. Located inside Villa Reale, [GAM Milano](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/gam-milano/) houses the largest municipal collection of 19th-century artworks in Italy. There is free admission to the gallery from 4:30 pm daily and from 2 pm on Tuesdays.

items.title: Stroll along the canals at Navigli and Porta Ticinese
items.caption: The districts of [Navigli and Porta Ticinese](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/navigli-porta-ticinese/) have been important places for trade and commerce since the Middle Ages because of the canals and waterways that run through them. Today, this area is the heart of Milan’s nightlife, with streets full of lively bars and restaurants. It’s a great place for a relaxing waterside stroll and people watching.

items.title: Discover underground art and culture at MACAO
items.caption: The [MACAO](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/macao/) art project began in 2012 with the "occupation" of an empty skyscraper in downtown Milan. After various adventures (including being evicted from the skyscraper by police), its founders relocated to an old slaughterhouse in the city’s eastern suburbs to continue promoting underground culture and political participation. Now, MACAO has become a permanent meeting place for art-loving locals and visitors.

items.title: Escape the city rush at Parco Sempione
items.caption: Located between the beautiful Arco della Pace (“Arch of Peace”) and Castello Sforzesco (“Sforza Castle”), [Parco Sempione](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/parco-sempione/) is a charming place to spend a relaxing day. It has a peaceful atmosphere (rare for central Milan), making it one of the most-loved parks in the city. If you’re a fan of basketball, exciting matches take place between local youths at the little court near the amphitheater.

items.title: Unleash your inner geek at Milan Natural History Museum
items.caption:
The [Natural History Museum](http://www.likealocalguide.com/milan/milan-natural-history-museum/) is one of the oldest public cultural institutions in Milan. It was officially opened in 1844 on the site of an old convent, and the collections were moved to the Museum’s current location in the Porta Venezia public gardens at the beginning of the 19th century. It regularly hosts exhibitions and other events of great international importance, however its appeal is linked to its permanent palaeontology, mineralogy, zoology, botany, and entomology exhibitions. There is free admission on the first Sunday of every month.

__More From Like a Local:__

fields.name: Like a Local
fields.shortBio: Like A Local Guide is all about finding those cool and hidden spots that locals like to hang out at and missing the tourist traps. We have built a website and mobile app to bring the tips of locals around the world to your fingertips.

featureContentItems.hed: Fall in Love With These Heart-Shaped Islands Around the World
featureContentItems.dek: Love isn't just in the air—these heart-shaped islands prove it's in the water too.

items.title: Heart Reef, Australia
items.caption: This coral reef was discovered on the Great Barrier Reef back in 1975 and has been a popular tourist attraction ever since. [Air Whitsunday](http://www.airwhitsunday.com.au/) offers a number of sightseeing tours by land and water, but choose either the Panorama or the Reef & Whitehaven Scenic tour to ensure prime aerial viewing of the reef.

items.title: Galesnjak, Dalmatian Coast
items.caption: Romantics will be hard-pressed to find a more heart-shaped island than Galesnjak, which our  [Maphead expert Ken Jennings](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-09-08/is-this-the-worlds-most-adorable-island) recently called "the world's most adorable island." The fact that it's currently uninhabited doesn't stop couples from visiting, and the island's owners hope to host weddings some day.

items.title: Tavarua Island Resort, Fiji
items.caption: Romantics rejoice: [Tavarua](http://www.tavarua.com/) is one of the few heart-shaped islands where couples can actually stay. The all-inclusive tropical paradise features a private beach, 16 cottages, and plenty of watersports: perfect for a honeymoon.

items.title: Sarakiniko Beach, Greece
items.caption: While Sarakiniko Beach isn't an island, this heart-shaped beach *is* located on Milos Island, which is halfway between Athens and Crete. If Milos sounds familiar, that's where the famous statue of love goddess Aphrodite (aka Venus de Milo) was found. It's no surprise then that Milos also goes by the "Island of Lovers."

items.title: Mecklenburg Lake District, Germany
items.caption: This adorable island can be found in Mecklenburg Lake, part of Central Europe's largest lake region. The island is uninhabited, but don't let that stop you from a romantic outing by renting a houseboat or canoe to find it.

items.title: Anfi del Mar Resort, Spain
items.caption: The heart-shaped island at [Anfi del Mar Resort](https://anfi.com/) in the Canary Islands may be man-made, but it's a heart-shaped island nonetheless. Currently, the only way to access the island is to belong to the resort's timeshare program.

items.title: Flores Island, Indonesia
items.caption: This little patch of land off of Flores Island doesn't draw the same attention as its more high-profile cousins, just as Flores Island is overshadowed by Bali. But while you may not be able to visit the heart-shaped isle, you can enjoy some romantic downtime in a tropical region that hasn't yet been overdeveloped.

items.title: Petra Island, New York
items.caption: This tiny island made headlines in 2013 when rumors flew that Angelina Jolie bought it as a birthday gift for Brad Pitt for nearly $20 million. Alas, the rumor proved false, but luckily the island is still listed for sale on [Private Islands Online](http://www.privateislandsonline.com/islands/petra-island). About an hour north of New York City, it includes not one, but two houses designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, plus a helicopter pad. The price is "available upon request," but what's the price of true love?

fields.name: Meredith Rosenberg
fields.shortBio: Meredith Rosenberg is a contributing web producer at *Architectural Digest.*
fields.bio: [Meredith Rosenberg](meredithlrosenberg.com) is a contributing web producer and writer at *Architectural Digest.* She’s spent the past decade as a writer and editor, and most recently produced videos for *The Village Voice.* Her travels have taken her from Alaska to Morocco, with India next in her sights. In her downtime she practices as much yoga as possible and fantasizes about yoga (and non-yoga) vacations. She graduated from the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism.

featureContentItems.dek: Instead of giving a box of chocolates this Valentine’s Day, why not whisk your sweet-toothed loved one off to one of these chocolate-inspired hotels?
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Chocoholics will have sweet dreams at these chocolate-inspired hotels.
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Chocoholics will have sweet dreams at these chocolate-inspired hotels.

items.title: Boucan by Hotel Chocolat
items.caption:
St. Lucia

The founders of the British chocolate line [Hotel Chocolat](https://cnt.conde.io/hotels/soufriere/boucan-by-hotel-chocolat) bought St. Lucia’s oldest cocoa estate—a 140-acre working plantation surrounded by rainforest—and turned it into a hotel. Unsurprisingly, the sweet treat is an in-room amenity, and can also be found in plenty of dishes at the on-site restaurant. The antioxidant power of the cacao bean is also harnessed at the Cocoa Juvenate Spa, which offers treatments like facials, exfoliating scrubs, and mani-pedis.

items.title: Jade Mountain
items.caption:
St. Lucia

Chocolate lovers can get an inside look at how the stuff is made at [Jade Mountain](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/saint-lucia/soufriere/jade-mountain-st--lucia), which makes its own chocolate from cocoa beans grown at the resort. At the on-site Chocolate Laboratory, guests can sample all kinds of sweets, or—if you’re looking for something more hands-on—make their own fudge and chocolate bars. The resort also offers extended workshops, including a four-day Discover Chocolate Festival that happens every fall—it’s like paradise for the most dedicated chocoholics.

items.title: Chocolate Boutique Hotel
items.caption:
Bournemouth, UK

Owners Gerry and Roo Wilton opened the [Chocolate Boutique Hotel](https://cnt.conde.io/hotels/bournemouth/chocolate-boutique-hotel) in 2007, and have been offering—as the name would suggest—a chocolate-heavy experience for guests ever since. The cocoa theme begins with the rooms, decorated in delicious shades of brown and with thematic names like Xocoatl or Mocha. Chocolate-tasting and –making classes are also on offer, and there are even themed packages that bring a private chocolate fountain to your room.

items.title: Roses & Xocolate
items.caption:
Mérida, Mexico

You can’t miss this [beautiful boutique hotel:](https://cnt.conde.io/hotels/merida/rosas-and-xocolate) It’s housed in two colonial mansions that were painted with a bright-pink façade. The hotel’s owners partnered with Mathieu Brees, a Belgian chocolatier who owns his own chocolate store, Ki'Xocolatl, in Mérida, to provide goodies to hotel guests. The hotel spa, meanwhile, incorporates cocoa into several of its treatments, including an exfoliating manicure and a firming facial.

items.title: Viceroy Zihuatanejo
items.caption:
Zihuatanejo, Mexico

While this [romantic Mexican hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/zihuatanejo/viceroy-zihuatanejo) isn’t chocolate-themed per se, it does offer plenty of ways for chocophiles to indulge around Valentine’s Day. A special chocolate dinner for two happens right on the beach, and features the sweet ingredient used in a number of savory ways. There will also be a more casual tasting in the hotel’s Coral Bar, where guests can sample truffles, mousse, and other delectable items.

items.title: Hugo Hotel
items.caption:
New York, NY

Winter in New York can be cold and bitter, so warm up by planning a night around the [Hugo Hotel’s](https://cnt.conde.io/hotels/new-york/hotel-hugo) seasonal hot chocolate menu. This isn’t your childhood cup of Swiss Miss: The grownup-friendly offerings include warming drinks like the __Dirty French__ (flavored with Chartreuse) and __L’Orange__ (a combination of hot chocolate, Cointreau, and Drambuie).

items.title: The Langham, Boston
items.caption:
Boston, MA	

Prepare to be overwhelmed: [The Langham Boston’s](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/boston/the-langham-boston) Chocolate Bar, which is open for Saturday brunch, features more than 100 dishes that incorporate the cocoa bean and its variants, inspired by cuisines around the world. Buffet stations feature crepes, chocolate fountains, and chocolate lava cake. The hotel has also recently unveiled a special chocolate-themed suite, where cocoa-dusted items are on a special en-suite menu, candy is featured prominently, and chocolate-inspired movies are available to watch.

items.title: Peninsula Chicago
items.caption:
Chicago, IL

When staying at the [Peninsula Chicago](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/chicago/the-peninsula--chicago), make sure to leave room after dinner for Chocolate at the Pen, the hotel’s chocolate buffet, available on Friday and Saturday evenings. Items vary from one week to the next and a dedicated “Chocolate Sommelier” is on hand to assist with tough decisions.

items.title: Adelphi Hotel
items.caption:
Melbourne, Australia

In 2013, [Adelphi Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-11-21/inside-adelphi-hotel-melbourne-australia-dessert-themed-hotel) reinvented itself as a dessert-themed hotel—with carpets patterned to look like cakes and furniture resembling candy. Desserts take center stage at the hotel’s restaurant Om Nom—including the “Basil Garden” (dark chocolate, vanilla, olive oil, honey, basil, lime, white chocolate, and meringue).

items.title: Hotel Sacher Vienna
items.caption:
Vienna, Austria

Although its claim to the label has caused some controversy in the past, [Hotel Sacher Vienna](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/austria/vienna/hotel-sacher--vienna) insists that its version of the famed chocolate cake is *the* original Sachertorte, made using the recipe perfected by Franz Sacher in 1832. The sweet treat features apricot jam spread over layers of chocolate cake, and it’s served throughout the hotel (alongside cups of Sacher coffee). You don’t even necessarily have to go to Vienna to get a piece: The hotel also sells cakes online.  

------------------

[Inside 'the World's First Dessert-Themed Hotel'](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-11-21/inside-adelphi-hotel-melbourne-australia-dessert-themed-hotel)

featureContentItems.hed: Tips for Taking Amazing Photos on a Cruise
featureContentItems.dek: Grab your camera and get ready to set sail with 10 photos you must take on a cruise from photographer and travel expert Me Ra Koh.

items.caption: My husband and I have the best job! We produce a travel show with our kids and teach [photography workshops around the world](http://www.merakoh.com/2015/01/29/learn-how-to-take-photos-in-italy/). Our most recent [workshop](http://clickretreat.com/) was for a group of sixty plus top mom bloggers on the Caribbean’s largest cruise ship, Oasis of the Seas.  With all levels of photography, we captured inspiring imagery. Whether you have a smartphone or DSLR, here are 10 photos you must take a cruise.

items.title: It’s a Ship, Not a Boat.
items.caption: It became a running joke among our group whenever one of us referred to this massive ship as a boat. The intimidating size of a [cruise ship](http://www.royalcaribbean.com/findacruise/ships/class/ship/home.do?shipClassCode=OA&shipCode=OA&br=R&wuc=USA&cid=ps_agt_yh_14311) is worth capturing. Consider taking this photo when you exit the ship in the early morning for an excursion to take advantage of the beautiful morning light.  Or wait until the late afternoon when you return for a golden light like I did for this photo. I purposely included the smaller ship to the far left because it gives scale to how large our cruise was.

items.title: Watch for Cloud Shadows in Landscape
items.caption: There will be a handful of opportunities to get up high and shoot down on the beautiful landscapes, whether it’s from the upper deck of the cruise or a viewpoint on your excursion. Watch for clouds that cast shadows over the land. The shadows help add more depth and emotion to the overall landscape. You can see how [Pint Size Baker](http://www.pintsizedbaker.com/)  did a wonderful job of capturing all the different dimensions of light.

items.title: Detail Detective
items.caption: Not only do you want to take the super wide angle photo of beautiful landscapes, but you also want to be a Detail Detective.  What are details that make your cruise experience unique?  Hanging from the ceiling of our group’s dining room entrance were bright colored Chinese lanterns. My husband used a [Lensbaby](http://www.amazon.com/s/?_encoding=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&field-keywords=lensbaby&linkCode=ur2&sprefix=lensbaby,stripbooks,245&tag=merakophbl-20&url=search-alias=electronics&linkId=CKUXJB3ASGIDG4Z5%29%20with%20his%20SONY%20DSLR%20%28http://www.amazon.com/s/?_encoding=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&field-keywords=sony%20a7&linkCode=ur2&rh=n:172282,k:sony%20a7&sprefix=sony%20a7,electronics,173&tag=merakophbl-20&url=search-alias=electronics&linkId=2EPQU7MD2DQY2TTA) to get this special kind of result straight out of the camera.

items.title: Food Idea 1: Shoot Straight Down
items.caption: Food is a big part of the cruise experience, whether you enjoy the local flavors or the endless options on board. There are so many fun ways to photograph your food journey, I must include three. First, you can shoot down on the food like Nicole from [Wonky Wonderful](http://wonkywonderful.com/) did. Just stand up over your food with a smartphone or DSLR and shoot straight down. She also used a great app called [Studio Design](http://www.madewithstudio.com/) to add text to her image.

items.title: Food Idea 2: Capture the Action
items.caption: You can also capture the action of food being prepped for you. Alyssa from [Simply Quinoa](http://www.simplyquinoa.com/) did a wonderful job of capturing the motion of the guacamole being made at our tableside. Experiment with a slow shutter speed to capture motion like this.

items.title: Food Idea 3: Get in Super Close
items.caption: One of my favorite ways to photograph food is to get in super close with the camera. I love how Jamie from [Totally the Bomb](http://totallythebomb.com/) not only got in close, but she also off centered the bowl of avocado.  Seeing a subject in part can add interest to a photo’s story.

items.title: The Staff’s Story
items.caption: Our group was so impressed with the staff’s attention to every detail. The staff went the extra mile to make our cruise experience amazing. You can’t help but want a photo of them! You could have your favorite staff members look at the camera and smile (but that’s what everyone does).  Why not do something different? What about capturing a story of who they are and what they do. I love how Carina of [The Jet Set](http://www.jetsetcarina.com/) captured the waiters as they were getting the run down on the evening’s dinner menu. Changing it to black and white was a great choice because of the contrast in their black and white uniforms, and it drew our attention to the waiter’s face that much more.

items.title: Color Groupings
items.caption: While doing your excursions, look for color groupings to photograph. My eye was drawn to the pretty blue and white combination in this gelato stand. Maybe your eye is captured by the line of red umbrellas along the beach or the blue towels rolled up in perfect order poolside. Give yourself a fun creative exercise for the day by looking for color groupings. You’ll be surprised at how much you find.

items.title: The Journey Photo
items.caption: Look for ways to capture a moment that says “journey.” It can be a photo of your feet standing on the sand. Or it can be a moment like this. I love how Molly of [Mommy Coddle](http://mommycoddle.com/) has her subject in the far right side of the frame and fills the middle and left side with the turquoise ocean waters. Just the simple composition choice to off center your subject will help convey a sense of “journey” in your photo.

fields.name: Me Ra Koh
fields.shortBio: Me Ra Koh, The Photo Mom, Disney Jr host of show “Capture Your Story” & Sony Artisan of Imagery. [www.merakoh.com ](http://www.merakoh.com)
fields.bio: Me Ra Koh, affectionately known as The Photo Mom, is the leading photography expert and educator to moms with cameras. She hosts the Disney Junior TV show *Capture Your Story with Me Ra Koh*. Not only do tens of thousands of moms follow her blog for photo tips, travel inspiration and creative empowerment, but she also writes for Disney’s Babble and Conde Nast Traveler in which she inspires moms to not only capture their family but live their best life.  She is the author of the national bestselling series, *Your Baby in Pictures: The New Parents’ Guide to Photographing Your Baby’s First Year* and *Your Child in Pictures: The Parents’ Guide to Photographing Your Toddler and Child from Age One to Ten* and *Your Family in Pictures: The Parents’ Guide to Photographing Holidays, Family Portraits, and Everyday Life* reaching #1, #2 and #3 at the same time on Amazon’s Top 10 Best Seller List. Me Ra was the guest photography expert on *The Nate Berkus Show* for two years (NBC). She is proud to be one of the select SONY Artisans of Imagery since 2007.  Her writing, photography, and photo recipes have been featured on *The Oprah Winfrey Show*, Lifetime Television, VH1, and Martha Stewart Living Radio, as well as in the *New York Times*, *Parenting*, *Yahoo Shine, American Baby, Women’s World, Associated Press, Huffington Post, Popular Photography, American Photo*, and *CLICK*. Her award winning photography has been exhibited from coast to coast. Her Egypt photography was given the honor of being on exhibit in The Natural History Museum in NYC. Her instructional DVDs, *Refuse to Say Cheese* and *Beyond the Green Box*, both won the prestigious national Gold Seal Award from National Parenting Publication Awards. Her CONFIDENCE Photography Workshops for Women have sold out for six years.  Me Ra and her husband also mentor a hand-picked nationwide team of CONFIDENCE Teachers who teach their photography workshops, empowering moms in their local communities. She works closely with partners like Disney, SONY, Sesame Street, Southwest Airlines, select travel companies, and Target to find ways to inspire the creative hearts of moms. You can even find her smile at your local Target and Best Buy! Her current project is producing a television show for families with her husband, Brian Tausend, director and cinematographer, and two children, plus a guerilla film crew, as they travel the world. Me Ra is a sought after, inspirational keynote speaker who brings empowerment, humor and tears to all her audiences. She is afraid of escalators in big cities, scuba diving and rock climbing, but she does all three (unless an elevator is nearby). Find her at [www.merakoh.com](http://www.merakoh.com/).

featureContentItems.hed: Video: Inside The Carlyle, New York City’s Most Storied Hotel
featureContentItems.dek: In our new video series *Hotel Stories* we reveal the personalities and stories behind our favorite hotels around the world. This week: The Carlyle, on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.
featureContentItems.body:
Every U.S. president since Harry Truman has visited [The Carlyle](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/the-carlyle--new-york). The historic Upper East Side property, steps from Central Park, has also played host to visiting royals and heads of state, including the late Diana, Princess of Wales, and more recently, Prince William and Kate, Duchess of Cambridge. But you don’t need to be a dignitary to visit. You don’t even need to book a room. Just act like a New Yorker and saunter into Bemelmans Bar just after 5 p.m., pull up a chair beneath the gold-plated ceiling, and enjoy live music as you sip your martini.
 
In this episode of *Hotel Stories* we speak with Bemelmans pianist Earl Rose, learn the art of the 30-second conversation from elevator operator Allen Davison, and catch a glimpse of those hand-monogrammed pillowcases. 

Subscribe to [Condé Nast Traveler on YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/condenasttraveler) for the next installment of *Hotel Stories.*

featureContentItems.hed: How to Get Through an Airport in Record Time
featureContentItems.dek: As a photographer and *Conde Nast Traveler* editor, I spend hundreds of hours navigating through airports each year. I can attest that getting through the airport quickly and efficiently is an art form, one that is learned through careful observation and experience. Here are some of my best tips for how to do it with lightning speed.

items.title: Get priority status on the airline you fly the most
items.caption: Airline loyalty programs offer faster (in theory) check-ins, including security points, in some airports. They will also tag your bags for priority handling, which in some cases means seeing your bags appear early on the baggage claim roundabout.

items.title: Take advantage of the skycaps and curbside check-in
items.caption: If you are checking bags and the lines inside are long, this is the best use of your money. These guys are pros, helpful and knowledgeable. (They should also be tipped generously for this.)

items.title: Dress for security
items.caption: Do we have to remind you that METAL sets off a METAL detector? This means keep the metal in your wardrobe at a minimum if you want to breeze through the machines and get to your gate: leave the bling, studded boots, rings, and belts at home, or at least put them in your bag. Remember to empty your pockets of all that change as well.

items.title: Remember: No liquids over 3.4 oz
items.caption: It is the simplest of rules to understand: Remove that bottle of water, along with any other large bottled liquids, from your bag. Buy your water or fill your (BPA-free, of course) bottle after going through security. If you simply must take 12 ounces of shampoo or moisturizer, then check that bag! And don't forget that clear plastic bag to tuck them all into.

items.title: Apply for TSA Precheck
items.caption: [TSA Precheck] (http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-06-23/future-of-airport-security) puts you in a dedicated line that is often quicker—you don’t have to take your shoes off, you can leave laptops and iPads in their cases, and you can usually skip the full-body scanner. Similarly, [Global Entry] (http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-06-23/why-it-s-worth-it-to-sign-up-for-the-tsa-global-entry-program) for International travel allows you to skip the immigration line and head to one of the automatic kiosks. There is also a dedicated U.S. customs exit for Global Entry passengers.

items.title: Don’t dilly-dally
items.caption: Walk quickly, use people movers (stand left walk right people!), take stairs, and do whatever else is needed to keep moving things along.

items.title: Use roller luggage
items.caption: I [mostly check bags] (http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-11-17/10-packing-mistakes-to-avoid/1), but if I just have a carry-on (a surefire way for a speedy exit off the plane), I mostly use a four-wheel roller – they roll quickly and take corners well.

items.title: Sit near the front of the plane
items.caption: Using miles or airline loyalty programs can help you snag the best seat. If you want to be up and out as soon as possible, choose an aisle seat, and business or economy comfort is ideal. This strategy usually puts me up nearest the exit for [quick departure from the plane](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-11-19/how-to-get-off-the-airplane-and-through-immigration-in-12-minutes).

items.title: Don’t push
items.caption: Please, [don’t be the pushy passenger] (http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-11-17/10-packing-mistakes-to-avoid/10) trying to run off the plane once it has touched down. It just creates a bottleneck, and everyone gets mad. Everyone is eager to get off the plane, so calm down, be patient, and wait your turn. The exit happens faster that way. If you've planned ahead the way I suggested, you should be all ready to get going.

items.title: Observe the pros in action and follow suit
items.caption:
The "pros" are mostly savvy business travelers, and they're easy to spot: look for suits, gold-toed socks, Tumi luggage, and lack of gear. They get through every step of the process. When in doubt, imitate them.

Related:   
[What to Wear to Breeze Through Airport Security](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-10/what-to-wear-to-breeze-through-airport-security)

[How to Get Off a Plane and Through Immigration in 12 Minutes](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-11-19/how-to-get-off-the-airplane-and-through-immigration-in-12-minutes)

[The Best and Worst Airports in America](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-11-24/the-best-and-worst-airports-in-america-readers-choice-awards-2014)

featureContentItems.dek: What's more romantic than a getaway for two? Here are some clever tips for making it happen.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53da4f6fdcd5888e145ad093]||||||





##PERMISSION TO DAY-DRINK

Caroline Campion of the cooking site [devilandegg.com](devilandegg.com) was treated to a surprise trip to Charleston by her husband. “We spent an afternoon at the Pavilion Bar in the [Market Pavilion Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/charleston/market-pavilion-hotel--charleston), drinking bourbon cocktails with a couple we’d just met,” she says. “We’d normally never do that, and we’ll never see them again, but for 24 hours they were our best friends. There are certain cities that let you just be, and this is one.”

##THE PLAN IS NO PLAN

In every couple, there’s always a designated planner. One example is Christine Amorose of the lifestyle blog [cestchristine.com](cestchristine.com). But for a recent trip to the Dominican Republic with her boyfriend, the only thing she booked in advance was the hotel. No restaurants, no activities—just four nights at [Casa Bonita in Barahona](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/baharona/casa-bonita-tropical-lodge). “It was sort of spontaneous, which took the pressure off me,” she says. “We were in it together.”

##REWRITE THE SCRIPT

When writer Ashlea Halpern’s boyfriend said he wanted clothes for his birthday, her initial thought was, *Boring!* But then she got to work on his real present. “I asked an art director friend to design a faux Topman gift card for $500, but I rewrote the fine print to say that it was redeemable at one specific Topman—the one in Prague, which I had booked a secret trip to,” she says. (And yes, he actually went to the Prague Topman.)

##SPLURGE ON YOUR HOTEL

You’ll probably spend more time in the room when it’s just the two of you, so book one you’d want to sleep until noon in. The private *maisons* at [Auberge du Soleil in Napa Valley](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/st-helena/auberge-du-soleil--napa-valley) overlook the hills of wine country and come with a terrace, a fireplace, and a steam shower (for two, of course). On the East Coast, you won’t do better than the turret suite at the Castle Hill Inn in Newport, Rhode Island. The cozy, wood-paneled, bi-level suite has panoramic ocean views.

##MAKE YOUR BUSINESS TRIP DO DOUBLE DUTY

Wherever interior designer Maca Huneeus and her vintner husband’s work takes them, they plot a trip to the most exotic place they can travel to easily—and quickly (they have four children back home). When her husband had to attend Vinexpo in Bordeaux, they used it as the jumping-off point for four nights at [La Maison Arabe](http://www.lamaisonarabe.com/) in Marrakech. “The more remote the place, the more bonding you do,” she says. “We’re in major cities all the time and know them so well. The unknown is much more romantic.” For L.A.–based photographer Dewey Nicks, however, getting away is less about place than a state of mind: “We tack shorter trips in the U.S. onto assignments and leave the kids with their grandparents.” And while it’s not Marrakech, it’s still romantic. “It’s nice to have a great dinner and stay in a hotel with your wife,” he says. “That and no jet lag make for a really good vacation.”

*For more romantic travel ideas, check out our [Romantic Getaway Guide](https://cnt.conde.io/reports/special-report-romantic-getaway-guide).*

featureContentItems.hed: Don’t Steal That Fluffy Towel: Hotels May Be Tracking You With a Linen Chip
featureContentItems.dek: Think before you take that bathrobe home with you: Hotels are using small tracking devices to combat theft of missing linens.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: Don’t Steal That Fluffy Towel: Hotels May Be Tracking You With a Linen
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Hotels are using small tracking devices to combat theft of missing linens.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: Don’t Steal That Fluffy Towel: Hotels May Be Tracking You With a Linen Chip
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Hotels are using small tracking devices to combat theft of missing linens.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54d29f0ff743358e0c1dc981]||||||





Those fluffy, white hotel towels may be a nice souvenir from your luxury hotel stay, but resist the temptation to tuck one inside your bag.

Hotels, which report losing up to 20 percent of their linens every month, are cracking down on linen theft with the help of an electronic tracking device sewn into towels, sheets and robes that can tell users when and where the items are being stolen. 

The devise is barely perceptible to those who aren't looking for it, and sneakier still, Linen Tracking Technology, the company behind the microchip trackers, won’t reveal which hotels they're working with. 

The company did say about 2,000 hotels now have their devices in their towels.

“Our properties like to remain anonymous. They benefit from the gained efficiency and don’t want to alert guests that they have this technology,” William Serbin, executive vice president of Miami-based Linen Tracking Technology told the Daily Mail.

While the company has been around for several years, more hotels in U.S. and overseas have been adopting the Linentracker chip, with some reporting a huge decrease in linen theft. The [Mr. C Hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/los-angeles/mr--c-beverly-hills) in Beverly Hills [says the device reduced their rate of missing items](http://www.rfidjournal.com/articles/view?10953/2) from between 20 to 30 percent each month down to just 3 percent.

The M&M candy-sized chip, which can be attached to linens, towels, or robes—and alerts managers to where they are at all times—can last through up to 300 wash cycles.

The company initially created the chip to allow hotels to keep better track of linens shipped to offsite cleaners, where the majority of theft of misplacement occurs—between 10 to 20 percent monthly, Serbin estimates. Two percent of hotel linen theft can be directly attributed to guests.

“Our solution not only provides total inventory information, but provides additional data like dwell time, wash count, and laundry reconciliation, which assists properties become more efficient,” the executive vice president said.

But when one of the micro-chipped linens passes through a signal at the hotel’s entrance or exit, hoteliers are alerted that a towel has left the property. The chip does not currently report back the exact coordinates of the towel, but Serbin says hotels can make note of which guest stayed where in order to allow for better linen accounting.
